seo.description: Compare OpenPanel vs PostHog. Discover why teams choose OpenPanel as their PostHog alternative for simpler analytics with better privacy, lighter SDK, and no complex pricing tiers.

highlights.title: Key differences at a glance
highlights.intro: Here's how OpenPanel and PostHog compare on key factors.

items.label: SDK Size
items.notes: OpenPanel's SDK is over 20x smaller than PostHog's core library, resulting in faster page loads and better Core Web Vitals.

items.label: Cookie-Free by Default
items.notes: OpenPanel is truly cookie-free out of the box. PostHog requires specific configuration for cookieless tracking with reduced functionality.

items.label: Pricing Complexity
items.notes: OpenPanel has straightforward pricing. PostHog bills separately for events, recordings, feature flags, surveys, and more - each with different tiers.

items.label: Self-Hosting Complexity
items.notes: OpenPanel self-hosting requires just Docker. PostHog needs multiple services including ClickHouse, Kafka, Redis, and PostgreSQL.

items.label: Focus
items.notes: OpenPanel focuses on doing analytics exceptionally well. PostHog bundles 10+ products which can create complexity for teams just needing analytics.

faqs.title: Frequently asked questions
faqs.intro: Common questions about switching from PostHog to OpenPanel.

items.question: Is OpenPanel really free?
items.answer: Yes! OpenPanel offers a generous free tier with 10,000 events per month. Self-hosting is completely free with no limits. PostHog also has generous free tiers (1M events, 5K recordings) but costs can scale quickly with usage.

items.question: Why switch from PostHog to OpenPanel?
items.answer: Teams switch for several reasons: simpler pricing without multi-product metering, smaller SDK size (2.3KB vs 52KB+), true cookie-free tracking by default, easier self-hosting, and a focused analytics experience without feature bloat.

items.question: What features will I lose switching from PostHog?
items.answer: PostHog includes feature flags, session replay, surveys, and A/B experiments in their platform. If you actively use these, you'd need separate tools. If you primarily use PostHog for analytics, OpenPanel provides everything you need with less complexity.

items.question: How does OpenPanel compare on privacy?
items.answer: OpenPanel is cookie-free by default - no configuration needed. PostHog uses cookies by default and requires specific setup for cookieless mode, which disables some features like cross-session user identification.

items.question: Can I self-host OpenPanel?
items.answer: Yes! OpenPanel runs in a simple Docker container with ClickHouse. PostHog self-hosting requires multiple services (ClickHouse, Kafka, Redis, PostgreSQL) and has official limitations of around 100k events/month for single-server hobby deployments.

items.question: Is PostHog more feature-rich than OpenPanel?
items.answer: PostHog offers more products (10+ including feature flags, session replay, surveys, A/B testing, data warehouse). However, this comes with added complexity. OpenPanel focuses on doing analytics exceptionally well with a simpler, more focused experience.

items.question: How do SDK sizes compare?
items.answer: OpenPanel's SDK is 2.3KB gzipped. PostHog's core library is 52KB+ gzipped, though they lazy-load additional features like session replay. The difference impacts page load times and Core Web Vitals.

items.question: Which is better for startups?
items.answer: Both offer generous free tiers. PostHog provides more features out of the box (feature flags, etc.) but with more complexity. OpenPanel is simpler to set up and understand, making it ideal for teams that want focused analytics without the overhead of an all-in-one platform.
